channel.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
channel.description:
Since this question has come up a few times I thought that I would write a summary listing the pros and cons of each method. The idea is to be able to paint on top of the canvas.
[b]Double Buffering[/b] Unless you want the text to flicker you need to use double buffering. Basically you give the client something to draw on, then you draw on it, then you paint that to the screen. If you don't use double buffering, you and the client will interfere with each other when you draw on the screen at the same time. Sometimes the client will paint first and then you so your text will be visible. Other times you paint first and then the client paints over the top so your text isn't visible. Since this is all random you'll get an annoying flickering as each thread fights to paint first.
[b]Method 1: Simply paint on the canvas[/b] The simplest but inefficient and visually annoying since it doesn't use double buffering. [code]Graphics g = client.getComponentAt(1,1).getGraphics();[/code] You paint on that Graphics object. On the positive side you don't modify the client, you don't modify the API objects that the client uses and its simple. Negatively it'll suck up CPU more than any other method and the flickering will be annoying. [b] Method 2: Subvert the call to Canvas.getGraphics()[/b] The most efficient way requiring the fewest resources but it requires hacking of the API classes and the client. Contrary to FUD created by certain people who wish to peddle their own colour-based bots: byte code modification is not as detectable as reflection. Why? you can do everything you can do with reflection but with the bonus of being able to do more things. Think of it like a tool. You could wave it about like an idiot and draw attention. Or you could use it properly and more efficiently.
Somehow you make the client call your version of Canvas.getGraphics(). Rather than returning the actual graphics of the canvas, you draw on a buffer, paint the buffer to the Graphics returned by the actual Canvas.getGraphics() method, then return the Graphics of the buffer. What happens is: the client paints on your buffer, you then paint on the buffer, you then paint the buffer onto the screen, then you give the buffer to the client to continue the cycle. The result is that the screen is one frame behind but since there are 25ish frames per second it really doesn't matter.
Since the Graphics object is quite opaque it is hard to tell where it came from. You could be drawing on an in-memory image or on the screen or anywhere and the client wouldn't be able to know unless they dug through several layers of API specific (non-standard) variables with reflection. That means you can return any Graphics object. [b] Method 2a: Make the client's canvas extend a different class[/b] Rather than the client's canvas (We shall call it Canvas_Sub1) extending Canvas. We can make it extend our own class that then extends canvas. So: Canvas_Sub1 -> Canvas becomes: Canvas_Sub1 -> HackCanvas -> Canvas. In HackCanvas you override the getGraphics() method. The danger is that if the class hierarchy of the Canvas_Sub1 is checked then the hack will be obvious. RSBot uses this method.
[b]Method 2b: Make the Canvas_Sub1 call a different getGraphics method.[/b] Whenever the client calls a method "getGraphics" where the signature has no parameters and returns a Graphics object, you make it call your own static method instead. So from canvas.getGraphics() it becomes Bot.getGraphics(canvas). No complex byte code modification is involved since only one instruction is changed. The issue with this method is that the painting code could bypass it with reflection but this is highly unlikely and if you pay attention to the code in the client you'll be able to see it. If they do bypass it then the only effect is that your text won't be displayed.
Alternatively if Canvas_Sub1 overrides getGraphics then you just need to intercept calls to super.getGraphics(). Reflection could not bypass it.
[b]Method 2c: Make the Canvas call a different getGraphics method.[/b] A bit more complicated. Basically change the getGraphics method in the Canvas class. You could rename the method and add your own method with just enough logic to call your own method in another class. For example: [code]public Graphics getGraphics() { return Bot.getGraphics(this, getGraphicsOld()); }[/code] Of course this code would have to be implemented in byte code so you use another class to do the actual logic and just write a shim layer. The drawback is a deep search with reflection of the Canvas class would turn up this new method.
Alternatively put your shim in when the old method would've exited. That way you don't make another method.
An even simpler method is to completely replace the Canvas class with your own version. Add the option: Xbootclasspath/p:"HackedCanvas.jar" to the VM arguments where HackedCanvas.jar contains your canvas with hacked getGraphics() method. You can take Canvas.java from the jdk's source. [credits to D e n v e r].
[b]Method 3: Make the canvas a lightweight component.[/b] This is Sun specific. Using reflection change the Canvas's peer to an instance of a lightweight peer. As a result the getGraphics() method will call the parent component's getGraphics and so on. To intercept the call you need to make your own component with an overridden getGraphics method. Then make the client a child of that component. The heavyweight peer is still there you need to destroy it so call its dispose() method using reflection. Since the Canvas is now lightweight you don't need to use heavyweight menus. Additionally it may make running multiple client's in tabs easier. An issue is that the client could override the getGraphics() method in which case this can be detected. An advantage is that it doesn't require byte code editing so it is simpler. [b] Method 4: Change what the Canvas paints on[/b] This is Sun specific. Change the SurfaceData of the Graphics object to that of a buffered image of the same size. You then use another thread to paint that buffered image onto the original surface data. A simplification of this method allows you to see whats on the screen for a colour bot. I don't have eclipse on this computer so I can't give details but I'll update this post later.
[b]Method 5: Hack the client itself[/b] Inject code into the client's paint method. Probably the best way is to intercept the call to Graphics.drawImage().
Hopefully that covers all possible ways to hack with the painting of the client. If you know of any others please comment.

item.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I know what lock does, I was asking if my code was the correct way to create a double buffer between two threads. I don’t think I need more than a simple Object lock?

Read full topic
item.source: How to Hack the Client's Canavs

item.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
item.dc:creator: @_Discardedx21 `Discardedx2`
item.description:
@_Discardedx21 wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:29, topic:299955”]I know this is a bump, but I wanted to make my painter run in its own thread so it didn’t slow the client when painting large gui’s.

can someone tell me if there is anything wrong with it?

client painter is what loops through my paintable interfaces and runescapecanvas extends the canvas class via Xbootclasspath

[code]package runescape.client;

import runescape.client.interfaces.Paintable;

import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
import java.awt.image.ImageObserver;
import java.text.AttributedCharacterIterator;
import java.util.Vector;

public class ClientPainter implements Runnable {

private Client owner;
private Vector<Paintable> events = new Vector<Paintable>();

public final Object lock = new Object();

private int width, height;

public BufferedImage image = new BufferedImage(984, 562, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB);

public ClientPainter(Client owner) {
    this.owner = owner;
    new Thread(this).start();
}

public void addPaintable(Paintable p) {
    events.add(p);
}

public void run() {
    while(true) {
        synchronized (lock) {
            Graphics2D g = (Graphics2D) getImage().getGraphics();
            g.setBackground(new Color(255, 255, 255, 0));
            g.clearRect(0, 0, width, height);
            for (Paintable p : events) {
                if (p != null) {
                    try {
                        p.paint(g);
                    }catch(Exception ignored) { }
                }
            }
        }
        try { Thread.sleep(10); }catch(Exception ignored) { }
    }
}

void update(int width, int height) {
    image = new BufferedImage(width, height, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB);
    this.width = width;
    this.height = height;
}

public synchronized BufferedImage getImage() {
    return image;
}

}
[/code]

[code]public class RunescapeCanvas extends Component {

public BufferedImage image, off_screen;
public Graphics graphics;
private Client client;

public RunescapeCanvas() {
    image = off_screen = new BufferedImage(984, 562, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB);
}

public Graphics getGraphics() {
    if(client == null) {
        client = ClientRepository.get(getClass().getClassLoader().hashCode());
        client.updateCanvas(this);
    }
    if(image.getWidth() != getWidth() || image.getHeight() != getHeight())
        image = off_screen = new BufferedImage(getWidth(), getHeight(), BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_RGB);
    if(super.getGraphics() != null) {
        synchronized (client.painter.lock) {
            off_screen.getGraphics().drawImage(client.painter.getImage(), 0, 0, null);
            image.getGraphics().drawImage(off_screen, 0, 0, null);
            super.getGraphics().drawImage(image, 0, 0, null);
        }
    }
    return (graphics = off_screen.createGraphics());
}

public void update(Graphics g){
      paint(g);
}

}
[/code][/quote]

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/locks/Lock.html

Read full topic
item.source: How to Hack the Client's Canavs

item.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I know this is a bump, but I wanted to make my painter run in its own thread so it didn’t slow the client when painting large gui’s.

can someone tell me if there is anything wrong with it?

client painter is what loops through my paintable interfaces and runescapecanvas extends the canvas class via Xbootclasspath

[code]package runescape.client;

import runescape.client.interfaces.Paintable;

import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
import java.awt.image.ImageObserver;
import java.text.AttributedCharacterIterator;
import java.util.Vector;

public class ClientPainter implements Runnable {

private Client owner;
private Vector<Paintable> events = new Vector<Paintable>();

public final Object lock = new Object();

private int width, height;

public BufferedImage image = new BufferedImage(984, 562, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB);

public ClientPainter(Client owner) {
    this.owner = owner;
    new Thread(this).start();
}

public void addPaintable(Paintable p) {
    events.add(p);
}

public void run() {
    while(true) {
        synchronized (lock) {
            Graphics2D g = (Graphics2D) getImage().getGraphics();
            g.setBackground(new Color(255, 255, 255, 0));
            g.clearRect(0, 0, width, height);
            for (Paintable p : events) {
                if (p != null) {
                    try {
                        p.paint(g);
                    }catch(Exception ignored) { }
                }
            }
        }
        try { Thread.sleep(10); }catch(Exception ignored) { }
    }
}

void update(int width, int height) {
    image = new BufferedImage(width, height, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB);
    this.width = width;
    this.height = height;
}

public synchronized BufferedImage getImage() {
    return image;
}

}
[/code]

[code]public class RunescapeCanvas extends Component {

public BufferedImage image, off_screen;
public Graphics graphics;
private Client client;

public RunescapeCanvas() {
    image = off_screen = new BufferedImage(984, 562, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB);
}

public Graphics getGraphics() {
    if(client == null) {
        client = ClientRepository.get(getClass().getClassLoader().hashCode());
        client.updateCanvas(this);
    }
    if(image.getWidth() != getWidth() || image.getHeight() != getHeight())
        image = off_screen = new BufferedImage(getWidth(), getHeight(), BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_RGB);
    if(super.getGraphics() != null) {
        synchronized (client.painter.lock) {
            off_screen.getGraphics().drawImage(client.painter.getImage(), 0, 0, null);
            image.getGraphics().drawImage(off_screen, 0, 0, null);
            super.getGraphics().drawImage(image, 0, 0, null);
        }
    }
    return (graphics = off_screen.createGraphics());
}

public void update(Graphics g){
      paint(g);
}

}
[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

Nothing, it’s not like you can use opengl’s model vertex’s to identify models between updates and find their locations on screen to click? It’s not like they encrypt what the video card is doing, AT ALL. Not like they could if they wanted? They could protect it, but that’s an entirely different approach they don’t do, yet. I dunno, try a developer driver for a couple of days, and just have a nice watch… You could make an auto fighter without knowing the littlest bit about jaggl, java, and all that nonsense.

What am I telling you for, it’s not as if you guys have an original bone in your body? Just try to figure out what I mean, it’s straight forward.

[quote=“BAsh, post:24, topic:299955”][quote author=pplsuqbawlz link=topic=396252.msg3084146#msg3084146 date=1262386472]
yawn lol okay? im talking about grabbing opengl contexts?
[/quote]
It seems easier to keep everything in java rather than hacking around in a platform specific way.[/quote]

Not necessarily. Windows/Linux driver api’s are pretty damn closely matching. But yeah in some ways it is; but how many releases, bots, or other cheats have you seen that were actually coded without being platform specific. Most of the people on the cheating scene dont have any idea how to use the file systems correctly or anything like that. And the one’s that do run linux, have a windows, and a linux release? WTF Java = multiplatform = only need 1 release if you know what you’re doing! LOL

Personally I like the, security, hacking the game from outside of it entirely, provides. Currently there’s no “spyware” type watching like wow’s “warden” did, and blizzard was sued into submission for…

EDIT: The filesystem isn’t the only example; launching for example, you dont need a shell and a batch when the JAR and MANIFEST provide a multiplatform launching complex. There’s just too many ways to prove my point when working with… this place?

EDIT2: Now I’m bored of this place again… You guys had to make it un-fun

Read full topic

I love this place, it’s like the best amateur playground!

item.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The only way it would not be cross-platform is if there is a different version of Canvas.java for each platform, and since they only offer one Canvas.java to download, this cannot be the case and it has to work on all platforms.

Read full topic
item.source: How to Hack the Client's Canavs

item.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
item.dc:creator: @jimmy5410 jimmy5410
item.description:
@jimmy5410 wrote:

[quote=“Tenac, post:11, topic:299955”][quote author=D e n v e r link=topic=396252.msg2943448#msg2943448 date=1252062787]

Method 3: Make the canvas a lightweight component.
This is Sun specific. Using reflection change the Canvas’s peer to an instance of a lightweight peer. As a result the getGraphics() method will call the parent component’s getGraphics and so on. To intercept the call you need to make your own component with an overridden getGraphics method. Then make the client a child of that component. The heavyweight peer is still there you need to destroy it so call its dispose() method using reflection.
Since the Canvas is now lightweight you don’t need to use heavyweight menus. Additionally it may make running multiple client’s in tabs easier. An issue is that the client could override the getGraphics() method in which case this can be detected. An advantage is that it doesn’t require byte code editing so it is simpler.

No need for byte code Editing in any case, just Xbootclasspath/p:“HackedCanvas.jar” , in wich the HackedCanvas.jar contains your canvas with hacked getGraphics() method (Canvas.java taken from the jdk’s src).
[/quote]
I did this in the past and it worked great, no bcel required, but I heard that this only works on windows, and most bots would like to stay cross-platform I’m guessing.[/quote]
Who told you that?

Read full topic
item.source: How to Hack the Client's Canavs

item.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
item.dc:creator: @Tenac Tenac
item.description:
@Tenac wrote:

[quote=“D e n v e r, post:3, topic:299955”][quote author=BAsh link=topic=396252.msg2943397#msg2943397 date=1252057079]

Method 3: Make the canvas a lightweight component.
This is Sun specific. Using reflection change the Canvas’s peer to an instance of a lightweight peer. As a result the getGraphics() method will call the parent component’s getGraphics and so on. To intercept the call you need to make your own component with an overridden getGraphics method. Then make the client a child of that component. The heavyweight peer is still there you need to destroy it so call its dispose() method using reflection.
Since the Canvas is now lightweight you don’t need to use heavyweight menus. Additionally it may make running multiple client’s in tabs easier. An issue is that the client could override the getGraphics() method in which case this can be detected. An advantage is that it doesn’t require byte code editing so it is simpler.
[/quote]
No need for byte code Editing in any case, just Xbootclasspath/p:“HackedCanvas.jar” , in wich the HackedCanvas.jar contains your canvas with hacked getGraphics() method (Canvas.java taken from the jdk’s src).[/quote]
I did this in the past and it worked great, no bcel required, but I heard that this only works on windows, and most bots would like to stay cross-platform I’m guessing.

Read full topic
item.source: How to Hack the Client's Canavs

item.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:9, topic:299955”][quote author=qauters link=topic=396252.msg3076348#msg3076348 date=1261862316]
Can’t you draw lightweight components on heavyweight ones these days (see: http://java.dzone.com/news/a-farewell-heavyweightlightwei)
[/quote]

Well that is awesome and long overdue. That post seems to point to it being a JDK fix, which means I could compile code with that JDK release and it would work as expected on all supported JVM versions, but it seems like something was fixed in the JRE, which means that even though with the new version it works for you that anyone with a lower version it won’t work for. Anyone know more about this issue?[/quote]
The JDK provides several useful tools to convert source into class files. Thats all it does. The JRE contains the classes that you then interact with. The article makes reference to the JDK being updated. For the purposes of the article the JRE can be thought of as a subset of the JDK. In reality this fix is in the JRE. So anybody running the application with a JDK or JRE version less than ver 6 Update 12 does not have this fix.

Read full topic
item.source: How to Hack the Client's Canavs

item.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

qauters:

Can’t you draw lightweight components on heavyweight ones these days (see: http://java.dzone.com/news/a-farewell-heavyweightlightwei)

Well that is awesome and long overdue. That post seems to point to it being a JDK fix, which means I could compile code with that JDK release and it would work as expected on all supported JVM versions, but it seems like something was fixed in the JRE, which means that even though with the new version it works for you that anyone with a lower version it won’t work for. Anyone know more about this issue?

Read full topic
item.source: How to Hack the Client's Canavs

item.title: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Can’t you draw lightweight components on heavyweight ones these days (see: http://java.dzone.com/news/a-farewell-heavyweightlightwei)
Anyway just wrap the current peer? No need to make it lightweight or shit, just make your peer wrapper manage bot/game buffer and make that draw to the the actual peer, easy.

Read full topic

item.source: How to Hack the Client's Canavs
